On 8/23/06, Jason Rogers <jacaetevha@...> wrote:
> Perhaps I have=
 a warped sense of high-test-coverage but I have always taken
> it to mean
=
>
>    =B3covering all of the most likely cases and even most of the unlike=
ly
> cases=B2

This is generally what happens in the real world.

> not jus=
t
>
>    =B3one test per unit=B2.

Agreed.

> With this definition I would =
assume that approaching 100% is possible, but
> getting 100% is improbable.=
  In my 7+ years of unit testing, test-first, and
> TDD I have never develo=
ped a system in which I would be confident saying I
> had 100% test coverag=
e.  Maybe I am too much of a skeptic.

Nope. You sound realistic to me. I a=
rgue on the side of 100% unit test
coverage, but while that is my target, I=
 realise that real life will
most likely interfere and I will get less than=
 that. It's still the
only worthwhile target aiming at though.

Simon
